title: Part A
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe the ecological niche that is occupied by the dominant native plant community that inhabits region A, based on the distribution of biomes in the United States, such as any of the following:

· Region A is a desert environment where the dominant plant species are cacti and succulents.

· The plants in region A would be adapted to the high temperatures and low precipitation in the desert.

· Plants in Region A have adaptions to arid conditions (e.g., water storage, thorns, thick waxy skin).

title: Part B
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one climate characteristic difference between regions A and C that could be studied to help explain the western corn rootworm infestation rate difference between the two regions, such as any of the following:

· Region A is much drier (or less humid) than region C.

· Region A has much less precipitation than region C throughout the year.

· Region A has much higher daily average temperatures than region C.

· Region A has much greater temperature differences in a 24-hour period.

· Region A has a much longer warm period than region C.

title: Part E
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one impact that the increase in no-till soil preparation would likely have on the environment, such as any of the following:

· Reduction soil erosion

title: Part G
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not describe one environmental problem that is likely to result from the land use change to convert native grasslands to cropland, such as any of the following:

· The conversion to agriculture destroys the habitat of native species resulting in the loss of biodiversity.

· The loss of cover from native grasses increases soil erosion from wind and water.

· The harvest of crops/clearing of native grasses reduces carbon sequestration in biomass and soils.

· Agricultural activities increase the use of fertilizers or pesticides, which can run off and pollute waterways.

The response describes one environmental problem that is likely to result from the land use change to convert native grasslands to cropland, such as one of the following:

· The conversion to agriculture destroys the habitat of native species resulting in the loss of biodiversity.

· The loss of cover from native grasses increases soil erosion from wind and water.

· The harvest of crops/clearing of native grasses reduces carbon sequestration in biomass and soils.

· Agricultural activities increase the use of fertilizers or pesticides, which can run off and pollute waterways.

title: Part H
stimulusHtml: Select a point value to view scoring criteria, solutions, and/or examples and to score the response.
descriptions:
The response does not make a claim that proposes a solution to the environmental problem identified in part (g), such as any of the following:

The conversion to agriculture destroys the habitat of native species resulting in the loss of biodiversity (problem identified in part (g)).

· Establish areas of critical habitat in the cropland

The loss of cover from native grasses increases soil erosion from wind and water (problem identified in part (g)).

· Plant buffer zones around the edges of the cropland

· Plant crops using no-till agriculture

· Plant crops using strip cropping

The harvest of crops / clearing of native grasses reduces carbon sequestration in biomass and soils (problem identified in part (g)).

· Plant crops using no-till agriculture

· Plant trees along the edges of the cropland/create a forested area within the cropland

· Remediate soils with biochar, compost, crop residues, green manure etc.

Agricultural activities increase the use of fertilizers or pesticides, which can runoff and pollute waterways (problem identified in part (g)).
